headline: Trump-backed nominees lost in Georgia, but can Republicans escape the specter of Maga?
author: David Smith
sentences: The former president had been waging a personal vendetta against Georgia's governor Brian Kemp and secretary of state Brad Raffensperger for failing to overturn the 2020 presidential election in his favor.
In fact, it actively helps Republicans create the illusion that they have moved on from Make America great again (Maga) even as they continue to push its radical rightwing agenda.
But he went Maga by pushing hot button issues such as coronavirus mask mandates, transgender bathrooms and critical race theory and portraying his opponent as a woke liberal.
Some might take this as proof that his spell over the Republican party has finally been broken, but that is what the Republican party wants people to believe.
Trump handpicked former senator David Perdue and congressman Jody Hice to challenge Kemp and Raffensperger in the Republican primaries.
It was also a blow to Trump in a primary season where his scattergun endorsements have come up with a decidedly mixed win-loss record.
Don't insult Donald Trump but do everything to keep him away, was how columnist Peggy Noonan put it in the Wall Street Journal.
Neither should be mistaken for NeverTrumpers in the mould of Jeb Bush, Mitt Romney, Liz Cheney, Adam Kinzinger or Larry Hogan.
Youngkin projected the image of a safe, sane, old school Republican who could win back suburban and independent voters.
He never campaigned alongside the ex-president but also took pains to avoid criticizing him and alienating his base.
It all began with Glenn Youngkin, who last year won election as governor of Virginia as a Trump-lite Republican.
It was a tangible sign that even many Trump voters are now weary of stop the steal and eager to look forward.
The formula has been emulated in various ways by candidates facing extreme Trump-backed challengers.
He flirted with, but did not embrace, Trump's false claims of a stolen election.
It worked for Brad Little, the governor of Idaho, and now for Kemp in Georgia.
But studying Trump's recent record as kingmaker misses the point.
Donald Trump's big lie lost bigly in Georgia on Tuesday night.
Both parroted the big lie and both were soundly beaten.
